values.alignmentText: The Liffey corridor is urban and paved, yet within a DART ride we can reach Howth cliffs or Phoenix Park meadows, so the environmental trade-off is density versus nearby green escapes.
Rising precipitation and storm intensity; coastal flooding risk; less extreme heat than continental Europe.
Oceanic—cool summers, mild winters, frequent rain/overcast; long summer daylight, short winter days.
Annual PM2.5 hovers around 13 µg/m³ along the quays thanks to traffic and smoky-fuel bans still phasing in, so we’d keep an AQI app handy for the occasional winter inversion.
Low seismic risk; Atlantic storms possible; robust building standards.
Typical daytime 8-15 C (46-59 F); frequent light rain; humidity moderate; longer daylight Mar-May.
Typical daytime 15-20 C (59-68 F); occasional 22-25 C (72-77 F); generally low to moderate humidity; cool evenings.
Typical daytime 9-14 C (48-57 F); increasing rain/wind from October; daylight shortens steadily.
Typical daytime 4-8 C (39-46 F); rare deep freezes; damp cold with occasional frost/sleet; snow uncommon outside uplands.
Dollymount Strand, Killiney, and the Forty Foot are swift DART trips, but chilly Irish Sea water and frequent red-flag days keep swims seasonal for wetsuit lovers.
Roughly warmest Jul–Sep; otherwise chilly; wetsuits common.
Dublin’s charm is mostly Georgian streets and coastal cliffs; real alpine drama waits in Wicklow, so weekend trains or car-shares become part of our nature fix.
The €12.70 minimum wage is well-enforced, yet it trails the Living Wage (~€14) and can’t comfortably cover Dublin housing or childcare, so entry-level families feel squeezed.
Total compensation for Dublin senior engineers routinely reaches €90–120k plus bonuses or equity, yet sky-high rents mean we’d still need to budget carefully to stay ahead each month.
Dublin’s docklands keep Microsoft, HubSpot, Stripe, and a dozen consultancies hiring senior .NET engineers, so Trey can jump straight into cloud rebuilds while building founder relationships.
Niche demand concentrated in startups and some fintech/SaaS firms; roles appear irregularly and often expect polyglot skills.
Common for ICT roles via Critical Skills; reliable processes.
Low unemployment; GDP volatile due to multinationals; high cost of living.
Huckletree, WeWork, and dog-friendly cafés with fiber make remote work frictionless, and most Dublin employers now budget hybrid setups by default.
EU norms for leave and hours; team culture varies.
Legal max 48; typical around 39–40 in many sectors.
At least 4 weeks annually (plus public holidays).
Tech often 23–25+ days, varies by employer.
Commuters pack the Luas before 8:30 and school drop-offs jockey for curb space, so we’d block calendar buffers to keep Dublin’s hustle from bleeding into family time.
Primary drop-off around 08:50, Luas rides into Docklands for 09:30 standups, and after-school clubs until 17:45 mean dinners land close to 19:00 unless we meal-prep.
Saturdays swing between farmers’ markets in Marley Park, kids’ GAA in the Phoenix Park, and museum trips timed around rain bands; Sundays often end with an early roast and board games.
Phoenix Park, Imaginosity, and free national museums are weekend staples, yet cramped housing and rain squalls limit spontaneous backyard play.
Poly Coffee, Relationship Anarchy Ireland, and kink-friendly community spaces operate openly in Dublin, but schools and immigration paperwork still assume two parents.
Balanced; extracurriculars common; independence encouraged; verify school‑home load.
Safe-feeling neighborhoods and playground upgrades around Stoneybatter help, but pram access on buses and limited apartment storage keep family logistics tight.
English‑medium public schools; many with Catholic patronage; limited international schools; Irish taught.
ECCE hours are guaranteed, yet full-day creches in Dublin 2–8 book out before birth, so au pairs or childminders often bridge the gap until primary school.
National Childcare Scheme hourly subsidies; Child Benefit monthly; paid maternity benefit (PRSI-based), paternity and parents leave.
NCS available to legally resident families with PPSN; supports generally residency/PRSI-based; documentation and status checks apply.
Citizens can secure seats, yet Dublin’s catchment boundaries and Catholic patronage mean we’d navigate waitlists or commuter runs to reach a secular Educate Together school.
Visa holders enroll once they show proof of address and PPS numbers, but oversubscribed city schools push many newcomers into temporary offers or longer commutes.
International schools like St. Andrew’s and Nord Anglia exist, but €15k+ tuition and limited slots keep them a selective backup plan.
26+ weeks maternity benefit (PRSI-based), paternity leave, about 9 weeks parents leave; child benefit; flexible work practices rising.
Many supports tied to residence and PRSI contributions; some benefits require Habitual Residence Condition; check specific status.
Free Fees Initiative for eligible undergrads; SUSI grants based on income; wide HE options in Dublin/Cork/Galway/Limerick.
Non-EU often pay international fees; scholarships limited; pathways improve after longer residence or PR/EU status.
Increasingly egalitarian; traditional norms persist in pockets.
Visible in urban areas; acceptance growing.
Strong legal protections; parental leave improving; confirm details.
Broadly flexible; safety relatively high.
Evolving; caregiving more normalized.
Literary festivals, indie tech meetups, and quick Ryanair hops across Europe keep Dublin feeling both cosmopolitan and neighborly.
English dominant; Irish is co‑official; high English proficiency.
Significant liberal shifts (e.g., marriage equality, reproductive rights) alongside some conservative currents.
Niche in discourse; mainstream politics centrist/center‑left/right mix.
Secularization advanced; Church influence diminished but present in schools.
Generally moderate‑liberal; sex‑ed improving; verify local norms.
Dublin Pride, gender-affirming clinics, and queer-owned cafés give the kids normalized exposure to inclusive culture most days of the week.
Local GAA clubs and parent WhatsApp groups welcome newcomers, but high rents and expat churn mean friendships take deliberate follow-through.
Friendly, resilient, proud of heritage; outward-looking and pragmatic.
Positive toward EU partners; close but complex relationship with the UK.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Often seen as friendly, welcoming, and culturally rich.
Late pubs, queer nights at Mother, and 2am closing times make for lively weekends, but crowds and limited late-night transit keep us planning rides home.
Smart-casual layers and waterproof outerwear; clean sneakers/boots; understated tailoring for nights out.
Smart-casual with practical outerwear; midi dresses/knits, boots/sneakers; modest to contemporary looks.
Sea swimming at the Forty Foot, parkruns in St. Anne’s, and climbing walls like Awesome Walls fit our routines alongside the ever-present pub quiz circuit.
Gamers World, The Clockwork Door, and meetup-led RPG nights in Smithfield give Trey instant playtest tables and English-friendly campaigns any night of the week.
Whelan’s, Tradfest, and late pub gigs keep live music thriving, with comedy basements and queer club nights ensuring Sarah still gets adult evenings after bedtime routines.
Tech, parenting, LGBTQ+, and poly meetups pop up nightly around Dublin’s coworking hubs, so integrating into new circles mostly means choosing which Slack invite to accept.
DART, Luas, and GoCar make it easy to bounce from city center to Howth headlands or Wicklow trails, but slots book up fast on sunny weekends.
Parliamentary republic; PR‑STV voting; multiparty coalition governance common.
Generally secular governance; residual church influence in education/health.
EU standards; unions present; termination processes regulated; non‑competes limited/enforceability varies.
Market‑friendly with social supports; strong MNC presence.
Low; independent media/judiciary; EU member checks.
Open economy; corporate tax reforms ongoing per OECD.
High political and economic stability; protest risk low‑moderate.
Low systemic propaganda; normal political messaging.
Focus on economy, services, housing; standard partisan frames.
Robust anti‑discrimination; LGBTQ+ legal recognition; reproductive rights.
Moderate; varies with housing/health outcomes.
Low by EU standards; transparency relatively strong.
More administrative/planning than overt; enforcement present.
Three-bedroom rentals in family-friendly neighborhoods like Ranelagh or Clontarf routinely top €3,200 monthly and trigger bidding wars, so landing a lease means compromises on space or commute.
Central Dublin feels safe by US standards, though teen antisocial behavior near O’Connell Street and occasional protests mean we stay alert on late DART rides.
Public system with long queues for some services; many carry private insurance.
Private insurance often required; access to public services depends on residency status—verify specifics.
National subsidies help, but popular Dublin creches have year-long waitlists and charge €1,100–€1,400 for infants even after the NCS credit, so backup carers are essential.
Supports for families; verify benefits by status and income.
Dublin’s primary schools deliver strong literacy and coding clubs, but denominational patronage and oversubscribed Educate Together campuses require early applications.
The DART, Luas, and dense bus network cover our daily needs, yet BusConnects construction and evening gaps still mean the family keeps Leap cards and occasional car-share credits.
Open market economy with EU social protections.
PAYE with USC and PRSI; yearly self‑assessment if needed; credits for couples.
Progressive bands; mid‑to‑high effective rates when including USC/PRSI—model scenarios.
Opening accounts generally requires photo ID and proof of Irish address; a PPSN is helpful but not always mandatory. Retail banks plus fintechs support widespread contactless payments.
Dublin stacks Dublin Airport convenience against €6 lattes, €1,600 infant creche fees, and high energy bills, leaving limited room for savings unless we command top-tier pay.
State Pension (Contributory) from about 66 with sufficient PRSI; occupational/private pillars common; EU portability good.
Eligibility depends on PRSI contributions and residence; private/occupational schemes portable; state benefits require contributions.
Critical Skills Employment Permit (CSEP), General Employment Permit (GEP), intra‑company transfer, student, family routes; Startup programmes via Enterprise Ireland.
Generally positive; high presence of US companies; straightforward processes.
Stamps (1/1G/4 etc.); CSEP can lead to Stamp 4 after a period; GEP longer path.
Naturalisation typically after ~5 years of reckonable residence (with continuity requirements); dual citizenship allowed.
Partner work authorization often available (e.g., Stamp 1G with CSEP spouse); confirm current policy.
Processing times vary by route; expect weeks to months; fees apply.
Track tax residency days; keep GNIB/IRP renewals current; maintain health insurance as required.
Yes - dual nationality permitted; subject to other country rules.
GNIB/IRP registration, PPSN, address proof; track tax residence days; private health cover early on; rights vary by stamp.
Keywords Studios, Vela Games, Riot’s support teams, and indie collectives around The Digital Hub make Dublin the country’s densest game-dev scene, though roles still cycle in bursts.
[Keywords Studios](https://www.keywordsstudios.com) (HQ Dublin), [Vela Games](https://velagames.com) (Dublin), [WarDucks](https://warducks.com) (AR/VR); plus indies.
[Imirt — Irish Game Makers](https://www.imirt.ie) (national association/network).
Enterprise Ireland grants, Dogpatch Labs accelerators, and easy networking with ex-Riot or EA staff give a Dublin studio launch a credible funding and mentorship path.
Gigabit fiber, 5G, and a resilient power grid backed by hyperscale data centers keep downtime rare even in older terraces.

Weather is generally predictable yet each season carries a couple of notable extremes that require monitoring and contingency planning. Seasonal Weather at 8/10 and Natural Disasters at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for seasonal extremes & variability.

Noticeable winter darkness arrives but we can maintain energy with regular outdoor breaks and occasional light therapy. Seasonal Weather at 8/10 and Environment at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for seasonal sunlight hours.

Two to three strong seasons offer great weather while shoulder months require occasional adjustments. Seasonal Weather at 8/10 and Environment at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for pleasant weather windows.

High living costs erode quality of life; reliable childcare or healthcare coverage often falls through the cracks. Minimum Wage at 6/10, Housing Situation at 3/10, and Childcare Support (Citizens) at 7/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for quality of life – lower-income tier.

Housing and childcare strain the budget, limiting savings and discretionary spending most months. Typical Software Salaries at 8/10, Housing Situation at 3/10, and Work-Life Balance at 8/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for quality of life – middle-income tier.

Premium experiences exist but feel overpriced, shallow, or socially frowned upon. Housing Situation at 3/10, Private Education at 5/10, and Family Life at 7/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for quality of life – higher-income tier.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Spacious rentals are rare; we likely settle for smaller homes or relocate to a different metro. Housing Situation at 3/10 and Cost of Living (Optional) at 4/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for spacious housing benchmark (2k sq ft rent).

We can find a few reputable co-living or cooperative projects though demand may require patience. Community Vibes at 7/10, Meetups & Communities at 9/10, and Family Life at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for community living opportunities.

Locals are polite and willing to connect when we show initiative, though relationships build gradually. Community Vibes at 7/10, Meetups & Communities at 9/10, and Common Hobbies at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for friendliness & neighborliness index.

Generally welcoming yet periodic political rhetoric creates mild concern. Welcoming of US Migrants at 8/10, Progressivism at 8/10, and Language & English Ubiquity at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for immigrant sentiment – general.

Mostly comfortable integration though some circles question motives or commitment to the country. Welcoming of US Migrants at 8/10, Language & English Ubiquity at 8/10, and View of Them by Neighboring Countries at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for immigrant sentiment – white migrants.

Politeness is situational; some contexts feel brisk but respectful. Community Vibes at 7/10, Nightlife Culture at 7/10, and Common Hobbies at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for surface interaction norms.

Relationships deepen steadily with consistent effort; vulnerability is appreciated though not automatic. Community Vibes at 7/10, Meetups & Communities at 9/10, and What Is Intriguing at 9/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for depth-seeking social norms.

Most locals read body language well, though some settings skew closer than we prefer. Community Vibes at 7/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 8/10, and View of self at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for personal boundary & bubble norms.

Openness is usually welcomed though some contexts expect diplomacy and softening of hard truths. Progressivism at 8/10, What Is Intriguing at 9/10, and Trust in Government at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for moral, honesty & openness expectations.

Noticeable emphasis on grooming means we budget extra time and money to fit in. Fashion Trends (Male) at 6/10 and Fashion Trends (Female) at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for grooming & beauty investment.

We notice subtle comparisons; maintaining confidence requires occasional boundary setting. Fashion Trends (Male) at 6/10, Fashion Trends (Female) at 6/10, and Sex (Attitudes) at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for body image & fitness pressure.

Fashionable appearance is expected in many settings, adding planning time and costs. Fashion Trends (Male) at 6/10 and Fashion Trends (Female) at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for fashion & style expectations.

Most encounters are considerate though occasional missteps require direct communication. Sex (Attitudes) at 8/10, LGBTQ+ Attitudes at 9/10, and Nightlife Culture at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for flirting boundaries & consent culture.

Mostly flexible though some circles still expect traditional roles on first approach. Gender Roles at 8/10, Gender Fluidity at 8/10, and Sex (Attitudes) at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for gendered flirting expectations.

Acceptance varies—urban hubs are welcoming while suburbs expect discretion. Polyamory at 7/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 8/10, and Community Vibes at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for monogamy vs. non-monogamy acceptance.

Most peers are nonjudgmental but traditional families may gossip. Sex (Attitudes) at 8/10, Nightlife & Music at 9/10, and Community Vibes at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for promiscuity attitudes.

Openness varies; we find understanding circles but remain discreet with institutions. Polyamory at 7/10, Community Vibes at 7/10, and LGBTQ+ Attitudes at 9/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for group & multi-partner relationship attitudes.

We occasionally experience closer contact than preferred but can steer interactions politely. Community Vibes at 7/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 8/10, and Nightlife Culture at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for personal space & touch norms.

Laws are moderate; we occasionally encounter firearms but rarely feel threatened. Safety & Crime at 7/10, State Ideology at 8/10, and Political System at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for firearm laws & ownership culture.

Balanced approach: regulated markets exist alongside education and support. Progressivism at 8/10, Political System at 8/10, and Safety & Crime at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for controlled substance policies.

Most enforcement is targeted though occasional crackdowns create unease. Safety & Crime at 7/10, Progressivism at 8/10, and Authoritarian Backsliding Risk at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for drug enforcement climate.

Recent history shows sporadic mass violence, so we stay vigilant at large gatherings. Safety & Crime at 7/10 and Stability at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for mass violence incidence.

Conditions are generally decent though some facilities lag in services or transparency. Authoritarian Backsliding Risk at 8/10, Safety & Crime at 7/10, and Perceived Corruption at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for carceral conditions & prison labor.

Infrastructure is inconsistent; safe walking requires choosing specific neighborhoods. Public Transportation at 7/10, Housing Situation at 3/10, and Nature Access at 7/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for walkability & pedestrian safety.

Healthy living requires self-direction; fast food and sedentary habits dominate social life. Healthcare (Citizens) at 5/10, Work-Life Balance at 8/10, and Community Vibes at 7/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for community health consciousness.

Ultra-processed options crowd shelves; schools and events lean heavily on packaged snacks. Cost of Living (Optional) at 4/10, Community Health Consciousness at 6/10, and Fresh & International Cuisine Access at 9/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for processed food saturation.

We have plentiful access to quality produce and diverse restaurants with only rare gaps. Nightlife & Music at 9/10, Common Hobbies at 8/10, and Meetups & Communities at 9/10 steer the family toward an excellent outlook for fresh & international cuisine access.

Mental health burdens exist but are met with accessible services and open dialogue. Seasonal Weather at 8/10, Work-Life Balance at 8/10, and Community Vibes at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for depression prevalence.

Higher obesity prevalence indicates limited access to healthy routines in some areas. Community Health Consciousness at 6/10, Work-Life Balance at 8/10, and Cost of Living (Optional) at 4/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for obesity rate.

Noticeable clusters or industrial risks require diligence and perhaps neighborhood vetting. Environment at 7/10, Healthcare (Citizens) at 5/10, and Community Health Consciousness at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for cancer incidence.

Resilience is good with occasional layoffs offset by quick reemployment. Economic Health at 8/10, Remote-Friendly Culture at 9/10, and Typical Software Salaries at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for broader job market resilience.
